banner.message: This is the rewrite of the Matrix Connectivity Tester UI. Please report any issues you find on

home.title: Matrix Connectivity Tester
home.welcome: Welcome to the Matrix Connectivity Tester! This tool helps you verify your Matrix server's connectivity and configuration by running a series of automated tests on your homeserver. It therefor must be reachable by the public internet.
home.getting_started: To get started enter your Matrix server's domain name (e.g. "example.com") in the input field below and click "Run Tests".
home.find_server_title: How can I find my server's domain name?
home.find_server_description: Your server's domain name is the part of your Matrix ID that comes after the colon. For example, if your Matrix ID is "@username:matrix.org", then your server's domain name is "matrix.org".
home.find_server_help: If you're unsure about your server's domain name, you can check with your Matrix client application or contact your server administrator for assistance.
home.homeserver_label: What is your Matrix homeserver's domain name?
home.homeserver_error_format: Enter a valid domain name, such as matrix.org or example.com
home.statistics_hint: Select to opt-in into optional statistics collection which will be shown on the statistics page.

footer.license_text: All content is available under the

notfound.title: Page not found
notfound.check_address: If you typed the web address, check it is correct.
notfound.check_paste: If you pasted the web address, check you copied the entire address.
notfound.report_issue: If the web address is correct or you selected a link or button,

results.title: Test Results
results.intro_results: These are the results of the connectivity test for your Matrix homeserver.
results.intro_no_action: We expect that you will not need to take any action if everything is working correctly. If there are issues, please refer to the details below to help diagnose and fix them.
results.intro_technical: Note that many sections are very technical in nature and are mostly interesting to technical power users or server administrators.
results.intro_check_problems: If any issues were found, please start by checking the "Problems" section first.
results.all_working_message: Your homeserver is properly configured and reachable.
results.all_failed_message: Your homeserver is not reachable or does not meet requirements.
results.success_message: Your homeserver is properly configured for federation.
results.failure_message: Your homeserver is not reachable or does not meet federation requirements.
results.support_info_description: If you need assistance with your homeserver, you can contact the following support contacts:
results.no_support_contacts: No support information is available for this homeserver.
results.federation_problems_description: The following issues were encountered during federation testing. Please review the technical details to diagnose and fix these problems.
results.federation_generic_error: Federation testing failed, but no specific errors were identified in the connection reports. This may indicate network connectivity issues, firewall blocking, or the server not being accessible on the federation port (8448).
results.support_problems_description: The following issues were encountered when checking the support information:
results.client_server_problems_description: The following issues were encountered when checking the Client-Server API:
results.problems_summary: Encountered issues during testing and possible resolutions.
results.client_server_api_summary: Supported API versions and experimental features.
results.client_server_api_success_message: Your client will be able to communicate with the server using the Client-Server API.
results.client_server_api_failure_message: There was a problem communicating with the server using the Client-Server API.
results.client_server_api_see_problems: Please check the Problems section above for details about the Client-Server API issues.
results.connectivity_reports_summary: Detailed information about each host tested.
results.raw_data_summary: JSON data of the test results.
results.wellknown_warning_description: Your federation is currently working (likely via SRV records), but there are issues with your .well-known/matrix/server endpoint. While not immediately breaking, this should be fixed to ensure reliable federation and compatibility with all Matrix implementations.
results.cors_preflight_warning_description: Your server does not properly handle CORS preflight (OPTIONS) requests. While the API is accessible, browser-based Matrix clients like Element Web may have connection issues. This only affects web clients, not mobile apps or desktop clients.

experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc2432: Updated authorization rules for alias events
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3026_busy_presence: Additional presence state for busy status
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc2716: Import message history into existing rooms
experimental_features_desc.uk_half_shot_msc2666_query_mutual_rooms: Query rooms shared with another user
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3771: Read receipts specifically for message threads
experimental_features_desc.fi_mau_msc2815: Allows room moderators to view redacted content in events
experimental_features_desc.fi_mau_msc2659_stable: Provides a ping endpoint for application services to check connectivity
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3882: Allows an existing session to sign in a new session without re-authentication
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3881: Allows a user to remotely toggle push notifications for another client
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3874: Allows filtering of threads from the /messages endpoint
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3912: Allows redaction of related events in a room
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3981: Allows recursion in /relations queries to fetch related events
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3391: Provides an API to delete account data for a user
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc4069: Allows users to inhibit profile information from being propagated to other clients
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc4028: Allows clients to push all encrypted events except for those in muted rooms
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc4108: Provides a mechanism for OIDC sign-in and E2EE setup via QR code
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc4140: Allows events to be sent with a delay
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_simplified_msc3575: The new sliding sync protocol prominently used by clients like Element X
experimental_features_desc.uk_tcpip_msc4133: Extends the User Profile API to support key-value pairs for user profiles
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc4155: Allows filtering of invites based on user preferences
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc2836: Introduces a threading model similar to Twitter for better conversation management
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc2946: Attempts to solve how a member of a space discovers rooms in that space
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3575: A new sync protocol that allows clients to receive updates in a more efficient way
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3916_stable: Provides a way to require authenticated media requests in Matrix
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3952_intentional_mentions: Makes mentions part of the json payload of a message instead of parsing the text content
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc4180: Adds a stable flag for MSC3916 to indicate that media authentication is now stable
experimental_features_desc.us_cloke_msc4175: Adds a profile field for user time zone to allow clients to display time-sensitive information correctly
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc4306: Allows users to subscribe or unsubscribe from threads to control notifications

server-resolution.srv_found_description: We were able to find the following SRV records for the server. This means we did not have to rely on the
server-resolution.srv_found_description_suffix: entry to discover the server's address.
server-resolution.wellknown_description_suffix: entry and found the following results:

connectivity-reports.details_summary: See details on Keys and Certificates

errors.missing_api_config: API configuration is missing or invalid.

error_solutions.docs_coming_soon: Detailed documentation for this issue is coming soon.

cors_federation.title: Connectivity Tester API Error
cors_federation.description: This error indicates a problem with the connectivity tester tool itself, not your homeserver. The backend API that performs federation checks is misconfigured or unavailable.
cors_federation.step1: This is not an issue with your Matrix homeserver - your server configuration is fine.
cors_federation.step2: Please report this issue to the administrators of this connectivity testing tool. The problem is with the testing service, not your server.
cors_federation.technical_note: CORS errors in federation context mean the backend federation-tester API is not properly configured. Federation checks should be performed server-side, not client-side.
cors_federation.learn_more: Learn more about the connectivity tester architecture

cors.title: CORS Configuration Issue
cors.description: Your server is not configured to allow requests from web browsers. This is a common security setting that needs to be adjusted for Matrix homeservers to work properly with web-based tools and clients.
cors.step1: Contact your server administrator or hosting provider if you're not managing the server yourself.
cors.step2: If you manage the server, you need to configure CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) headers. This tells browsers that your server allows requests from other websites.
cors.step3: Add the 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin' header to your server configuration. For Matrix, you typically want to allow all origins by setting it to '*' for public endpoints.
cors.step4: Restart your web server after making changes and test again.
cors.technical_note: CORS headers must be configured on your reverse proxy (like nginx or Apache) or directly in your Matrix homeserver configuration. The specific configuration depends on your server software.

cors_preflight.title: CORS Preflight Not Configured
cors_preflight.description: Your server is not properly configured to handle CORS preflight (OPTIONS) requests. This will prevent browser-based Matrix clients like Element Web from connecting to your homeserver.
cors_preflight.step1: Configure your web server or reverse proxy to respond to OPTIONS requests on Matrix API endpoints (/_matrix/client/* and /_matrix/media/*).
cors_preflight.step2: Ensure OPTIONS requests return the following headers: Access-Control-Allow-Origin (set to * or specific origins), Access-Control-Allow-Methods (must include GET, POST, PUT, DELETE), and Access-Control-Allow-Headers (must include content-type, authorization).
cors_preflight.step3: For nginx, add: 'if ($request_method = OPTIONS) { add_header Access-Control-Allow-Origin *; add_header Access-Control-Allow-Methods "GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS"; add_header Access-Control-Allow-Headers "Content-Type, Authorization"; return 204; }'
cors_preflight.step4: For Apache with mod_headers, use: 'Header always set Access-Control-Allow-Origin "*"' and 'Header always set Access-Control-Allow-Methods "GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS"' in your VirtualHost configuration.
cors_preflight.step5: After making changes, restart your web server and test again. You can test CORS preflight manually with: curl -X OPTIONS -H "Origin: https://example.com" -H "Access-Control-Request-Method: GET" -v https://yourdomain.com/_matrix/client/versions
cors_preflight.technical_note: CORS preflight requests are sent by browsers before making actual requests to check if the server allows cross-origin requests. Without proper preflight support, browser-based Matrix clients cannot connect. This only affects client-server API, not federation (which is server-to-server and doesn't use CORS).

not_found_support.title: Support Information Not Available
not_found_support.description: Your server doesn't have a support information endpoint configured. While this is optional, it's recommended so users can find help when they need it.
not_found_support.step1: This is not a critical issue - your server can work fine without it. However, having support information helps users contact you if they have problems.
not_found_support.step2: If you want to add support information, you need to create a file at /.well-known/matrix/support on your server.
not_found_support.step3: This file should contain JSON with contact information like email addresses or Matrix IDs for your support team.
not_found_support.technical_note: The support endpoint is part of MSC1929. It's a simple JSON file that lists contacts and support resources.
not_found_support.learn_more: Learn how to set up the support endpoint

not_found_client.title: Client Discovery Endpoint Not Found
not_found_client.description: Your server is missing the client discovery endpoint. This is required for Matrix clients to find your homeserver.
not_found_client.step1: You need to create a /.well-known/matrix/client file on your web server.
not_found_client.step2: This file must be accessible at https://yourdomain.com/.well-known/matrix/client (replace 'yourdomain.com' with your actual domain).
not_found_client.step3: The file should contain JSON that tells clients where your Matrix homeserver is located.
not_found_client.step4: Make sure your web server is configured to serve this file with the correct Content-Type header (application/json).
not_found_client.technical_note: This endpoint is crucial for client discovery. Without it, Matrix clients cannot automatically find your homeserver.

not_found_federation.title: Federation Endpoint Not Found
not_found_federation.description: Your server's federation endpoints cannot be found. This prevents other Matrix servers from communicating with yours.
not_found_federation.step1: Verify that your Matrix homeserver is actually running and accessible.
not_found_federation.step2: Check that your /.well-known/matrix/server file exists and points to the correct server location.
not_found_federation.step3: Ensure your firewall and network configuration allow incoming connections on the Matrix federation port (typically 8448).

content_type.title: Wrong Content-Type Header
content_type.description: Your server is sending responses with the wrong Content-Type header. Matrix requires all JSON responses to have 'application/json' as the Content-Type.
content_type.step1: This is usually caused by your web server or reverse proxy (like nginx or Apache) configuration.
content_type.step2: Check your web server configuration files and ensure they're set to serve .json files and Matrix endpoints with 'Content-Type: application/json'.
content_type.step3: If you're using nginx, you might need to add 'types { application/json json; }' to your configuration.
content_type.step4: After making changes, restart your web server and test again.
content_type.technical_note: The Content-Type header tells browsers and clients what kind of data they're receiving. Matrix requires 'application/json' for all JSON endpoints.

json_parse.title: Invalid JSON Response
json_parse.description: Your server is sending data that isn't valid JSON, or it's corrupted. This usually means there's a problem with how your server is configured.
json_parse.step1: Check your server logs to see if there are any error messages about the endpoint that's failing.
json_parse.step2: Verify that the files (like /.well-known/matrix/client or /.well-known/matrix/support) contain valid JSON. You can test JSON validity using online JSON validators.
json_parse.step3: Make sure your reverse proxy (if you have one) isn't modifying or corrupting the responses.
json_parse.step4: If the problem persists, try accessing the endpoint directly (not through this tool) to see what's actually being returned.
json_parse.technical_note: Common causes include: HTML error pages being returned instead of JSON, compression issues, or invalid JSON syntax in configuration files.

server_error.title: Server Error
server_error.description: Your server encountered an internal error while processing the request. This usually indicates a problem with your homeserver software or configuration.
server_error.step1: Check your Matrix homeserver logs for error messages. These usually contain details about what went wrong.
server_error.step2: Try restarting your Matrix homeserver service.
server_error.step3: Verify that your homeserver has enough system resources (memory, disk space, etc.).
server_error.step4: If the error persists, consider checking the issue tracker for your homeserver software (Synapse, Dendrite, etc.) or asking for help in their support channels.

timeout.title: Request Timeout
timeout.description: The request took too long and timed out. This could mean your server is very slow, overloaded, or there's a network connectivity issue.
timeout.step1: Check if your server is online and accessible. Try accessing it directly in a browser.
timeout.step2: Verify that your server has adequate resources (CPU, RAM, disk I/O). Server performance issues often cause timeouts.
timeout.step3: Check your network connectivity and firewall settings. Make sure requests aren't being blocked or delayed.
timeout.step4: Look at your server logs to see if the request was received and if there were any errors processing it.
timeout.step5: If your server is behind a reverse proxy or CDN, check their logs and configuration too.

network.title: Network Error
network.description: There was a problem connecting to your server. This could be due to network issues, DNS problems, or your server being offline.
network.step1: Check if your server is online by trying to access it in a web browser.
network.step2: Verify that your domain name's DNS records are correctly configured and pointing to your server.
network.step3: Make sure your firewall allows incoming connections on the necessary ports (443 for HTTPS, 8448 for Matrix federation).
network.step4: If you recently made DNS changes, they might not have propagated yet. DNS changes can take up to 48 hours to spread worldwide.

network_federation.title: Federation Network Error
network_federation.description: The federation tester could not connect to your server. This indicates your server is not accessible for federation or the server name configuration is incorrect.
network_federation.step1: Double-check your server name - it should be your base domain (e.g., 'example.com'), NOT a subdomain like 'matrix.example.com'. The server name is what users use after the ':' in their Matrix ID (@user:example.com).
network_federation.step2: Configure /.well-known/matrix/server delegation (recommended): Create a file at https://yourdomain.com/.well-known/matrix/server that points to your actual Matrix server location (which can be on a different port or subdomain).
network_federation.step3: If you're using a reverse proxy, ensure it's properly forwarding federation traffic from your domain to your homeserver.
network_federation.step4: Verify your Matrix homeserver is running and accessible. Check your homeserver logs for any startup or connectivity errors.
network_federation.step5: As a last resort, if not using .well-known delegation, configure DNS SRV records (_matrix._tcp.yourdomain.com) or ensure your homeserver is directly accessible on port 8448.

tls.title: TLS Certificate Error
tls.description: Your server's TLS/SSL certificate has a problem. Secure connections require valid, trusted certificates issued by a recognized certificate authority.
tls.step1: If you're using a self-signed certificate, you need to get a certificate from a trusted certificate authority. Let's Encrypt provides free, automated certificates. Note: Self-signed certificates can work in closed federations where all servers trust the same CA.
tls.step2: If you recently installed a certificate, make sure your reverse proxy or web server is configured to use it correctly and has been restarted.
tls.step3: Verify that your certificate is valid for your domain name and hasn't expired. You can check this using online SSL checker tools.
tls.step4: Ensure the entire certificate chain is properly installed, including any intermediate certificates provided by your certificate authority.
tls.technical_note: Matrix requires valid TLS certificates for secure communication. Self-signed certificates and certificates with unknown issuers will be rejected by most Matrix servers and clients unless they explicitly trust your certificate authority.
tls.learn_more: Learn about TLS certificates for Matrix

tls_federation.title: TLS Certificate Error
tls_federation.description: Your Matrix server's TLS certificate cannot be validated. This is blocking federation with other Matrix servers. Common causes include self-signed certificates, expired certificates, or certificates from an unknown/untrusted certificate authority.
tls_federation.step1: Use a certificate from a publicly trusted certificate authority. Let's Encrypt is free and recommended for Matrix servers. Note: Self-signed certificates only work in closed federations where all participating servers trust your certificate authority.
tls_federation.step2: If you're testing locally (127.0.0.1 or localhost), note that you cannot test federation with a local server. Federation requires a publicly accessible server with a valid domain name and certificate.
tls_federation.step3: Verify your certificate is valid for your server's domain name. The certificate's Common Name or Subject Alternative Name must match your server's hostname.
tls_federation.step4: Check that your certificate hasn't expired and that the full certificate chain is properly installed, including intermediate certificates.
tls_federation.step5: If you recently updated your certificate and use a reverse proxy (nginx, Apache, Caddy, etc.), restart the reverse proxy service. If TLS terminates at your homeserver, restart it instead.
tls_federation.technical_note: The Matrix federation protocol requires valid TLS certificates from trusted certificate authorities. This error typically shows 'UnknownIssuer' or similar messages. For development/testing, consider using a staging environment with a real domain and Let's Encrypt certificate rather than local testing.

invalid_response.title: Invalid Response Format
invalid_response.description: Your server returned data in a format that doesn't match what Matrix expects. This means your server isn't following the Matrix specification correctly.
invalid_response.step1: This usually indicates a problem with your homeserver software or configuration.
invalid_response.step2: Make sure you're running a current version of your homeserver software (Synapse, Dendrite, Conduit, etc.).
invalid_response.step3: Check that your configuration files are correct and follow the documentation for your homeserver software.
invalid_response.technical_note: Matrix has specific requirements for data structures. Your server's responses need to include certain fields and follow specific formats as defined in the Matrix specification.

missing_field.title: Missing Required Information
missing_field.description: Your server's response is missing information that Matrix requires. This indicates incomplete configuration or a bug in your homeserver software.
missing_field.step1: Review your server configuration files to ensure all required settings are present.
missing_field.step2: Make sure you're running an up-to-date version of your homeserver software.
missing_field.step3: Check your homeserver's documentation to verify that all required configuration options are set.
missing_field.technical_note: The Matrix specification requires certain fields to be present in responses. Missing fields usually indicate incomplete configuration or outdated server software.

unknown.title: Unexpected Error
unknown.description: Something went wrong, but we're not sure exactly what. This could be a temporary issue or something unusual with your configuration.
unknown.step1: Try running the test again - sometimes temporary network issues or server hiccups can cause one-time errors.
unknown.step2: Check your server logs for any error messages that might give more details.
unknown.step3: Make sure your server is running and accessible from the public internet.
unknown.step4: If the problem continues, consider asking for help in Matrix community channels or your homeserver's support forum.

wellknown_error.title: Well-Known Endpoint Error
wellknown_error.description: Your .well-known/matrix/server endpoint is returning an error (such as 400 Bad Request). While your federation may currently work via SRV records or direct connection, this misconfiguration should be fixed as it may cause issues with some Matrix clients and servers.
wellknown_error.step1: Check your web server configuration for the /.well-known/matrix/server endpoint. It should either return valid JSON with an 'm.server' field, or return a 404 if you're not using well-known delegation.
wellknown_error.step2: A 400 Bad Request usually means your web server is rejecting the request due to misconfiguration. Check if there are any request filtering rules, security modules (like ModSecurity), or incorrect rewrite rules affecting the .well-known path.
wellknown_error.step3: Ensure the .well-known/matrix/server file (if it exists) contains valid JSON. The file should look like: {"m.server": "matrix.yourdomain.com:8448"}
wellknown_error.step4: Verify that your web server is configured to serve .well-known files with the correct Content-Type header (application/json).
wellknown_error.step5: Test the endpoint directly in your browser or with curl: curl -v https://yourdomain.com/.well-known/matrix/server
wellknown_error.technical_note: The .well-known/matrix/server endpoint is the preferred method for server discovery according to the Matrix specification. While SRV records and direct connections on port 8448 work as fallbacks, relying solely on them is not recommended. A 400 error suggests web server misconfiguration rather than a missing file.

alerts.title: Server Alerts
alerts.intro: Set up alerts to be notified when your Matrix server goes down or becomes unreachable. You can register for alerts or manage your existing alerts.
alerts.register_description: Enter your email address and server name to receive notifications when your server experiences connectivity issues. You will receive a verification email to confirm your registration.
alerts.email_hint: We'll send you verification and alert emails
alerts.list_description: Enter your email address to receive a link to view and manage all alerts associated with your email.
alerts.list_email_hint: We'll send you a verification link to manage your alerts
alerts.email_verification_notice: All actions require email verification. Check your inbox for verification links.
alerts.register_success: Registration successful! Please check your email to verify your alert subscription.
alerts.list_request_success: Request successful! Please check your email for a link to view and manage your alerts.
alerts.missing_fields: Please provide both email and server name
alerts.missing_token: Verification token is missing. Please use the link from your email.
alerts.alerts_list_description: Below are all the alerts associated with your email address. You can request deletion of any alerts you no longer need. A verification email will be sent to confirm each deletion.
alerts.no_alerts: You don't have any alerts set up yet.
alerts.deletion_confirmed: Alert successfully deleted! The alert has been removed from your account.
alerts.alert_verified: Alert successfully verified! You will now receive notifications when your server experiences connectivity issues.
